title: Recirculating Ball Slide for 1" Square Tube

description.text:
Check out my improved version: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2492939

This low-friction slide uses 6mm plastic balls (airsoft pellets) in recirculating channels to provide unlimited rolling-contact linear motion. There are two ball circuits in each half that bolt together around a 1" square aluminum tube. The carriage can support side loads as well as moment and torque loads. This is a great low-cost alternative to using rollers and bearings on more costly (and heavy) extruded aluminum profiles.

This can also be scaled to 75% for use with standard .177 cal steel BB's and 3/4" steel tube. (Thanks, brw_racing! http://www.thingiverse.com/make:151352)

Update: This can also be scaled to 75% and used with standard .177 cal steel BB's running on 3/4" steel tube. Use M3 screws instead of the 8-32 screws.

The top and bottom halves are identical except that the top has thru-holes for 8-32 screws and the bottom has holes that can be tapped with 8-32 threads. Print both with 0.2mm layers, 3 perimeters and 35% infill. I printed them in PLA, but ABS should work fine. Make sure that your printer is printing the recirculating channels cleanly because there is no good way to clean out any blobs after the parts are printed. Tap the 4 holes in the bottom half with 8-32 threads. You may need to tap from both sides.

Fill each ball channel with 16 6mm airsoft plastic BB's. Make sure the balls all recirculate freely. Lubricate with a few drops of oil. Place your 1" aluminum tube on the top half, and carefully holding these two pieces together, flip them over and place on the bottom half. Screw together with four 1 1/4" long, 8-32 socket head cap screws. Use calipers to make sure the gaps on both sides are uniform. Tighten until there is no longer any play, but no more than that. There should be enough thread depth left in the holes on the bottom side to mount your load.

Additional printing tips:
There will be a small patch of solid infill lines at the very bottom of the bearing surface. Orient the solid infill so that these infill lines are parallel to the ball channels. You'll need to check the g-code preview to make sure you've got it right.

Set the starting point for the perimeter lines to be towards one end of the ball channels. This will prevent perimeter start/stop irregularities from appearing in the middle of the bearing surface.

comments.text: When I see the marks on your tube, you really should use anodized aluminium tube cause it has a much harder surface!
comments.author: FZS1_Fazer

comments.text: Probably better to used anodized tube, but the plastic balls don't really create much wear on the tube - the mark look like scratches in the photo, but they are actually more superficial.
comments.author: FZS1_Fazer

comments.text:
Howdy LoboCNC,
Nice piece, and something I believe can possibly work for my application...being a bit of a 'noob', how precisely do I reduce the file "75%" to work with 3/4" conduit (I'm presently just using Tinkercad)?
comments.author: USMC_Buckaroo

comments.text: You could scale the part in Tinkercad, but the simpler thing to do would be to scale it using using your slicer software.  Most slicers include an option for scaling the model before printing it.
comments.author: USMC_Buckaroo

comments.text: I wonder if there is a way for a metric size (20mm square tube), and the use of metal spheres.
comments.author: specie1980

comments.text: It might be possible to scale by 80% and use 5mm balls.  I'd stick with plastic balls, though, as metal ones will probably cut grooves in the aluminum tube.
comments.author: specie1980

comments.text:
This has been a wonderful design to play around with. I remixed a version of your slide that can be used for 3/4 inch tubing and the air soft pellets. also a version that uses 1.77 cal bb's good for 3/4 and 1/2 inch tubing.
I guess all that's left is to scale is a bb version up to 1 inch tube like your original design and possibly a airsoft pellet version down to 1/2 inch.... guess ill get started.
Ill tell you the reason im so jazzed about this bearing slide is im working on a new version of my cnc plasma cutter with a water table... I was always worried that splashes of water getting into normal bearings would probably not be good. I think your plastic pellet version scaled down to 3/4 is going to work great for me...
comments.author: brw_racing

comments.text: Very cool design!
comments.author: mkeveney

comments.text: This is awesome! I bet it is a lot quieter than bearings sliding on the aluminum too. Can't wait to print it.
comments.author: tonyallen28

comments.text:
The ones I made last year (based on Johann Rocholl's design) were quite noisy, so set your expectations accordingly.
https://plus.google.com/+StephenKongsle1/posts/3goQFLxu9Z9
comments.author: tonyallen28

comments.text: This is an awesome design! Any idea what the maximum load rating is?
comments.author: MechEngineerMike

comments.text: I actually have no idea of the load rating.  I don't even know for sure what the airsoft pellets are made of (ABS?).  My gut feeling is that it could handle straight vertical or horizontal loads (where at least two full rows of balls are fully engaged) of at least 20 lbs, but who knows - maybe a lot more.    That would also be equivalent to a torsional load of about 15 in-lb.  Moment loads would be a lot less because only a few balls are supporting the load, but for that type of loading, you'd probably want to use two carriages anyway.
comments.author: MechEngineerMike

comments.text: That's really cleaver and i think i have a use for some of these. I don't have airsoft pellets on hand but i have some BB's so will be printing this off and most likely scaling to work with steel bb's  4.35mm. possibly could make for a good remix or if you'd like to redesign it?
comments.author: brw_racing

comments.text: If you scaled it for steel BB's, it would probably work for running on 3/4" square tube instead of 1".  You might also want to use steel tube instead of aluminum because the steel BB's will wear grooves in aluminum.
comments.author: brw_racing

comments.text:

I believe scaling for smaller track should be simple also. Im thinking splitting the model at the valley or the v remove a few mm of width should work if someone were using smaller tube possibly same could be done to go larger also.
While tinkering with the scale think ill try and add captive nut holes.

author: vishal1222

title: Marvel Dice Masters divider for dice and cards

description.text:
This was made for photo boxes I found at Joanns:
http://www.joann.com/search?q=photo+box

I think it is a pretty standard sized photo box, they come in a lot of exterior styles and are super cheap.

This divider idea uses nickle storage containers for the dice. A link that worked at the time of posting this is:
http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=nickle+storage+tubes
Search for "nickle storage tube" on ebay or amazon and you should find a lot. They are pretty standard. They can get pretty cheap buying them in lots of 30+.

This design will fit the entirety of either of the first two sets of dicemasters, Including power dice and sidekicks. Extra dice may have to be stored elsewhere. Each nickle tube can hold up to 5 dicemasters dice. I have most of the first two sets, and put mine in alphabetically. This is the second box obviously. My first box was a custom made poster board solution which was a lot of work, which is why I did this for the second and hopefully future boxes.

Print two each of part1.stl and part2.stl
The cardtop.stl is optional.

I have included 123D files for the split up version that fits on a Lulzbot mini, and the fullsize version if you need to split it differently or can print it in one piece. (still have to cut of the card top I assume).

In my photo I am not using the top piece because I have not glued it together yet. This does demonstrate that you don't need to glue it, and you do not need the top piece.

If I did this again, I would make the walls thicker. They print pretty high and thin and with ABS, most of mine split (delaminated). The good thing is that this does not matter, the walls are just spacer anyway, I did not even bother trying to glue them back together.

author: vishal1222

description.text: The Z Voice Light uses motors and artificial tendons to achieve your next voice command. You can control the position of a light using your voice. This project is in the working progress, it is not completed yet. When the Z Voice Light is completed you will be able to use your voice to adjust where the light is positioned. The purpose for this mechanism is when a user is working on a project that requires both hands and needs to move their lighting, they can simply use their voice without taking the time to place down their tools and manually adjust the light.

The Z Voice Light began when I struggled holding a light while soldering a circuit board at the same time. I needed to re-position the light over and over again. The light it up challenge helped inspire my design and gave me the motivation to follow through with the idea.

Currently (July 2015) I am using a Diligence Uno32 Chipkit board, 4 hobby servo motors, fishing line, and an EasyVR 3.0 shield (I have not yet began testing the lamp using the EASYVR yet) and with the 3d printed parts posted.

In the files I have also included the concept art design, which is what I would like the final design to end up looking like.

Because this project is in the working progress, instructions will follow and be reposted as soon as I know what works best!

If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays LinkIt is a 2 player abstract strategy game created by Tyler Mills (Xyvir Games) with the goal of having a game that plays with only one type of piece and no board.

The goal of the game is to capture more of the board by the end than your opponent, a little like Othello. Each player chooses a color indicated by the main color of each 2 sided piece. Both player take turns placing tiles orthogonality to existing pieces (not diagonal) displaying their respective color side up and oriented any direction they wish. If one of the constructs listed below for your color are created their effect happen immediately. If that construct in turn generates a new construct for your color the new construct is played and the turn repeats until a construct does not create any new construct.

TurnIt! Exactly 4 tiles in a row, orthogonally or diagonally. Choose one of the four grouped tiles and turn it any other direction.
TakeIt! 2-5 adjacent opponent tiles in a row orthogonally with your tile on either side oriented so to point at each other. All enemy tiles in this construct are flipped to your side maintaining their orientation when flipped. Flipped LinkIt!s don't reactivate.
LinkIt! Two of your tiles adjacent and oriented to point at each other. You must take another turn after making this construct however you may only have one outstanding new turn at a time; they do not stack. Note #1: If a TurnIt! and TakeIt! construct form at the same time, the TurnIt! construct is ignored.
Note #2: If multiple constructs of the same kind are formed at the same time, you must only choose to utilize one of them.

Requires dual color printer.  
49 tiles in all are required. Since most printers can't print all 49 at once the sets have been broken up into 25 and 24 tiles each, or 4 tiles to test, then 25 and 20 to complete it. So long as 49 tiles are made in the end.

comments.text: Or, if you don't want to print them dual, just make a piece where the inner part is left out. Then you can switch filament colors halfway up so the two sides are opposite colors.

title: Sunfish Plug and Cap for Mast Well

description.text:
Keep rain, debris, and critters out of the Mast Well when the mast is not installed.

The Plug can be printed out of any plastic at any resolution or fill percentage.

I printed the gasket with NinjaFlex and it worked great. Any soft TPU should work - or you can just cut a strip of gasket material and glue it on to the Cap with contact cement.

My wife was complaining about how I had printed all these different docks for my stuff and she wanted one too. Well, I wasn't able to find one specifically for the 10 inch Tab 4, but did find one for the Galaxy Tab 10.1. While they are very similar in shape, the 10.1 uses a 30 pin connector while the Tab 4 10.1 uses the standard micro usb connector. So after a little work in OpenSCAD, I was able to make modifications to the Tab 10.1 and created this Tab 4 10.1 dock. Other than the spacing for the narrower plug, I had to add some extra height to the dock to accommodate the longer connector.

I put some holes on the bottom for rubber feet, but the ones I have were larger then I thought.

title: Parametric reprap gen7 motherboard mount clamp

description.text:
My previous motherboard â€œholderâ€ was just a big piece of plexiglass, held in place by zip ties, nice, but not â€œminimalâ€, nor quick, nor easy to make in series, and mostly, not reprapable :)
So i came up with these clamps, to be fited on the reprap's structureâ€™s threaded rods: they already hold well by simple tension, but are even more stable thanks to the inwards pressure once you screw the motherboard onto them.

All parametric, so please use the openscad file rather than the stls
-The Stl's are for M6 rods, and the for a "huxley" size machine, to accomodate for different rod diameter just change the "rod_dia" parameter
-for wider machines change the mount_hole_distance parameter : this is the distance between the center of one of your side rods and the place you want the motherboard's mount holes to be
-you can also make these "taller" (to mount the motherboard higher, see pics) by changing the mount_hole_vertical_offset param. These types of clamps become unsymetric though, so just set the "flp" param to generate the left and right versions

title: Car mountable Wireless Qi Charging Dock for Galaxy Note 4
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Wireless charging your phone while using it as GPS in your car. (Don't text and drive.)

The phone is Galaxy Note 4 with OEM charging back cover - which is slightly thicker than non-charging cover. Two designed as included here. v4 fits snug and v5 allows a bit more relaxed fit. Both are fitted enough to not fall off when driving.

This design, uses a common inexpensive Qi charger puck (I'm showing powerbot PB1020 but I also use simiplar looking pucks that look the same on my mounts)

This design is meant to be mounted with a 1/4" - 20 bolt (the tripod mount) I'm using 5/8" pan head bolt and RAM Mounts 1 Inch Ball with 1/4-20 Female Thread (part number RAM-B-348U)

It holds steady, no vibration. I'm happy with it. The reason picture doesn't match the model exactly is because the print failed due to failed material support in the end but it still worked perfectly. This design works great but is a bit of a pain with supports.

author: cfishy

description.text: Simple scale model demonstrating the "bundled tube" principle developed by Fazlur Khan, first used in the construction of the Sears Tower.

Needs various lengths of 1/2" Schedule 40 PVC pipe: 2 @ 204mm, 2 @ 271mm, 3 @ 373mm, and 2 @ 457mm. These lengths were calculated on the Tower's base of 225 ft. square and a height of 1450 ft., without antennae. All these numbers could be wrong, but it looks okay to me. This was a very simple project to build.
.
Once the novelty value has faded, you can cut the tubes in half and make something useful, like a dandy holder for artist's brushes.

Yes, I know it's now called the Willis Tower, but old habits die hard. It's the Sears Tower. Period.
Sliding letter puzzle

Inspired by a shattered light bulb, this design can be used to fit over an existing light fixture - in my case I wanted to save an old Ikea lamp that worked perfectly well, but the lampshade was old and ugly. Often old products like this are too easy to just throw away, when with a bit of 3D printing it can be re-invented and given a new lease on life.

The smallest inside diameter is 31mm so just make sure you can slide this over your intended light fixture - if not just scale the print up to fit! This particular print was done on an Up! Plus 2, using 0.2mm layer thickness. Very little support material was needed.

Read all the details about creating this design, and see more photos on my website https://edditiveblog.wordpress.com/2015/07/27/shattered-faceted-light/

title: NRG Energy (San Diego) Server Cabinet Blanking Panels

description.text:
While on vacation in San Diego, I saw a building that resembled server racks.

My #SeeTheWorld submission are these blanking panels for your server room that are functional, attractive and make your server cabinet look just like the NRG Energy Center building located at 934 Kettner Blvd in San Diego.

View on Google Maps

Each blanking panel (either 2U or 4U) is split up into three parts that should just about fill up the print area of a MakerBot Replicator Desktop. The parts have an overhang to hide the seams, so be sure to print with support. Once the print is complete, remove the support material; file, Dremel or sand paper until you get a snug fit; and glue together.

WARNING: This is a large surface area print that can be extremely difficult to unstick from your print bed, hence I do not recommend printing this on a bare print bed. I covered my print bed with blue tape and then poured Goo Gone around the completed print, allowing it to saturate the tape and weaken the adhesive.

comments.text: That's it, I'm putting a 3d printer in the budget so we can do this in the datacenter. Love it!
comments.author: cmh

Have fun making your own super bright LED head lamp. This Lamp uses seven 5mm, 35000mcd white LEDs and is powered by 3 AAA batteries.

Key Features: the tilting head allowing you to point the light where it is needed, there are no fasteners required (all connections are pressure fit), fully printed battery case, holes in back of battery pack provide easy removal of batteries, multiple piece assembly allows for custom color combinations, use of a bandanna as the head band provides a one size fits all solution and further opportunity to personalize the head lamp style, and circuit board templates for easy creation of circuit boards without the need for special tools.

This project utilizes simple electrical circuits and requires soldering and etching your own circuit boards.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WV7r3IZ_1yM
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6zzM-Atklvw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=06y_mV0xElw&feature=youtu.be

Printing:

All components of the head lamp can be printed at once, or print individually for different colored components.

Recommend printing with 3 shells and a layer height of 0.3mm with no need for support material.

Assembly:

See "LED_HEAD_LAMP.pdf" for assembly drawings and parts list.

  • Holes in the side of "HL-01 HEAD" may require a little clean up before inserting the side brackets. by hand, run a 3/16 drill bit in each of the holes. Be careful not to remove to much material or the head will be two loose and will not stay in position.

  • see attached videos for further assembly reference.

Circuit Boards:

  • Print the "PCB Template.pdf" and past it to the back of the copper clad board. Use this as a pattern to drill your holes and cut out the different pieces you need. Follow the pattern and color in the boards with the sharpie then etch your boards.

  • I recommend printing my "dremel table saw" to make your PCB cutting easier (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:877151)

  • Insure wires are long enough that the battery pack can be slid out one end of the side brackets so that batteries can be changed.

  • Before installing and soldering the 8mm switch, remove the two left most terminals.

Required materials:

-One-Side Copper Clad Single PCB Circuit Kit Board Glass Fiber (http://www.ebay.ca/itm/10PCS-One-Side-Copper-Clad-Single-PCB-Circuit-Kit-Board-Glass-Fiber-70x100x1-5mm-/400786163000?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item5d50b78538)

-x7 5mm White LED 35000mcd (http://www.ebay.ca/itm/231001318601?_trksid=p2060353.m1438.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)

-x1 8X8mm Blue Cap Self-locking Type Square Button Switch (http://www.ebay.ca/itm/301174122287?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)

-x1 10ohm resister (http://www.ebay.ca/itm/121608848582?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)

-18 to 24 AWG red and black wire

-Enchant (http://www.ebay.ca/itm/231164503346?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)

-Sharpie permanent pen

-1x Bandana (http://www.ebay.ca/itm/141654199723?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&var=440804594489&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)

-(Optional )10Pcs PCB Print Circuit Board Carbide Micro Drill Bits Tool 0.3mm to 1.2 mm (http://www.ebay.ca/itm/361251633854?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)

description.text:
Small led watch, with 3 working modes:

  • POV clock
    (More about this read at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persistence_of_vision)
  • Binary clock
    (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_clock . i have simple version here, without seconds, first row represents hours and second and third - minutes.
  • Flashlight
    All leds ON, so u can use it like small flashlight =)

Made 2 versions of watch case, but don't like both of them, will remake it soon.
I wanted to make it compatible with CLASP watchband (witch i remade slightly), but finally, when i printed it out, i didn't like it at all (perhaps it could be better in PLA or some more flexible plastic then ABS))
Debug circuitry on breadboard. Then I did the board layout, but during the installation accidentally have damaged the controller. There was no time to redo, so all pictures videos ​​with breadboard =( .
See instructions for Price summary and other info.
Feel free to ask anything else =)

Work is still in progress, wait for updates soon!

All u need to make it:
1 x AVR Atmega 8 ~ 4$
12 x LEDs ~ 3$
10 x 4k7-10k resistor ~ 0.1$
12 x 680R resistor ~ 0.1$
2 x 15pF capacitor ~ 0.01$
1 x 100nF capacitor ~ 0.001$ lol
3 x micro switches ~ 1.5$
1 x small Copper Clad Board ~ 2$
1 x COMS 3V CR2032 battery ~ 1.5$
so.. about 10-15$ for everithing..

U can download PCB layout it in lay6 format, Sprint-Layout 6 program can open it.
There is also a brain.HEX file - u should use it to install firmware on the AVR controller =) U can make it with Atmel AVR JTAGICE development tool or so..

Instructions
Use button 1 to enter setup mode ad switch to the next row (hours->ten min->one min).
Button 2 will increment data in selected row.
Button 3 exit the setup and switches modes POV -> Binary clock.

To use Flashlight u need to push button 1 and button 3 together.

After 15 seconds all leds goes OFF, to save battery life. Press button 2 to wake up.

Ever since I have known my husband (about 50 years) he has wanted to restore a salesman’s sample/patent model that he inherited from his grandfather, Eli Schrock. It is a 24” tall windmill with a 12” wheel. Some of the parts were broken or missing. When I saw the “catch the wind” competition, I suggested that we restore the model using printed parts to substitute for the missing or broken ones. So I started taking measurements and using 123Design, I was able to create what was needed. My spouse put the parts together and discovered the 1884 patent that his grandfather owned. A video of the finished model: https://youtu.be/NE-J6UeUEII

I then decided to try to build a working model of the windmill out of printed parts. Modifications had to be made to accommodate the change in materials. The most difficult part was the head of the windmill where circular motion changes to vertical motion. There are three versions laying on my desk right now and it still needs a little tweaking for smoother action. This is the only part that needs support when printed.

I am relatively new to 3D printing. Less than a year ago I purchased my first printer (a FlashForge Creator Pro) with the goal of learning a new hobby. I am now obsessed with 3D printing and using a second, recently acquired printer (a Lulzbot Taz 5). The Taz allowed me to make larger parts. The windmill is the largest project I have ever undertaken.

The windmill can be used in an educational setting to illustrate how wind can be used to pump water (ecology), to demonstrate how to change the direction of motion (engineering) or to show how the windmill helped to settle the Midwest U.S.A. (history).

Directions:
Most parts were printed with a layer height of .21 in PLA. Printing temperature was 210 and the bed temperature was 60. Other settings can be seen on the Cura Screen capture in the "Directions" file attached to this submission.

I used bamboo skewers for the main shaft. Pieces were connected using super glue, E6000 glue and fusing with a soldering iron. The wires on the front are scrap electrical wires.

This is a futuristic lightbulb I made using Autodesk Inventor.

I first made a cylinder, sketched two quarters of a circle opposite of each other on both of the circular sides of the cylinder, and extruded them on both sides. Next, I added two parallel planes that touched the surface of the cylinder, sketched two quarter circles across from each other, and extruded them. Finally, I added a yellow texture to make them look like lights.

title: Squashed frog replacement for repraps: parametric , printable

description.text:
This is one more element that used a big "vitamin" (non printed part)in my reprap that i wanted to replace.
The squashed frog is the part that is underneath the Y axis platform, and to which the belt as well as the bushings/bearings rolling on the rails are attached. The initial version was cut manually from plexiglass, but due to my lack of good quality tools/workspace, while it worked , it certainly would not have won prizes for quality ! So i decided to design a printable version, that had to :
be mechanically resistant enough
be relatively fast to print
be made of more than one part since it needed to be as big if not bigger than the maximum print size
have mounting point for the bushings as well as the belt clamps So this is the solution i came up with:
it is made of 3 parts , two of which are identical
it requires 4 nuts and bolts to be assembled
the inner holes with roundings enable the parts to be strong yet not use too much plastic
it is relatively fast to build and easy to assemble
*it works well ! I have yet to test it with a heated build platform but i am not too worried, because if the printed bushings of people using a hbp don't melt, then there is no reason for this to melt :) Very important : it uses the great bolted pla bushings by Griffin Nicoll available here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7157

IMPORTANT !
all parameters are tuned for my specific machine, so they most likely won't work for your specific needs! Please use the openscad file to generate the parts to the correct size. These are the most important things to change:
-platform_mount_x_distance: how far from the center should the mounting holes for the platform be
-platform_mount_y_distance: how far apart from each other should the mounting holes for the platform be
-smooth_rod_distance : distance between the Y axis smooth rods (from rod center to rod center)
  • All parameters related to your bolted bushings , and belt clamps
    • You will need to print two sides (i made the left/right sides seperate, but they really are the same part) , and one center element, then just assembled it all with nuts & bolts.

Light It Up any way you want to! This unique little lamp is fully customizable. All the side panels and top piece are interchangeable and replaceable. The Cowboy Bebop theme is just the start, with blank templates you could give this a look fully customized for you! More themes to come!

This is a project that I had wanted to make for a while now. Once i saw Light it up (albeit a bit late in the game) I knew i had to give it a shot. I'm still relatively new to 3d printing and wiring LEDs, so its had ups and downs throughout the process, but ultimately I'm glad i saw it through.

I started by designing the base panels and top piece. followed by printing them. Adjust as required. The design is pretty straight forward. slide the panels into the slots on the base, then place the top. As for the electronics i used 12 Bright white 3.2v LEDs Wired together in parallel, with 5.6ohm resistors, and a 4.5v power supply. If you know what your doing, you can try something different. The panels and top take about 2-3 hours to print on fast, the base took about a full 24 hours including supports.

This is a work in progress for an epic combination of Adafruit neopixels, and poi! Powered by a rechargeable Lithium ion battery, and controlled with an Adafruit trinket, all 30 of the RGB LEDs can individually be controlled for an amazing effect. This is an epic way to light up a summer night!

The designs are not perfect, but will be improving often!

Poi is a style of performance art, in which a performer spins 2 objects around themselves in many intricate patterns. Poi are often lit on fire, but for a safer and more colorful option, I chose to use LEDs instead!

Aside from the 3D printed parts, this project uses per poi :
Adafruit Trinket - Mini Microcontroller - 3.3V Logic
Adafruit Pro Trinket LiIon/LiPoly Backpack Add-On
1/2 Adafruit NeoPixel Digital RGB LED Strip - White 60 LED
16mm Illuminated Pushbutton - White Momentary
Breadboard-friendly SPDT Slide Switch

Basic soldering tools, and various wires are also used in this project

Sadly I have not yet had the time to put together a second model and complete the set. Stay tuned for updates, as they will be coming frequently. If this project receives 100 likes, I will post a detailed tutorial so that anyone can learn from my mistakes and maybe even light up their night!
